Thought Leadership Regarding the Internet of Things
by Jason Kridner

This article is still being updated. Please come back again tomorrow. :-)

With browsers and rich applications available to us everywhere, desires for information and control are growing astronomically. Entrepreneurial, design and cross-discipline engineering skills are all required to launch a successful connected device. Thankfully, Brian Delacy of MIT is exploring what it takes to educate individuals and teams on the required skills in the most expedient ways possible. I was fortunate to be a guest speaker at an IoT event he hosted at MIT and to participate in his week long Independent Activities Period (IAP) class, supporting use of BeagleBone Black.

This class had an amazing mix of people with different talents and interests. Starting on Monday, almost all of the class had no experience with BeagleBone Black and most had no experience with Linux either. Most of the lecture stayed focused on making sure the students had a view of the larger picture as well as typical pitfalls. By the end of the week, however, everyone built their own custom working project that communicated with the Internet and connected to physical sensors and actuators (like lights and motors).

Part of their success has to be attributed to getting grouped up with cross-disciplinary skills. This is something I've learned from other makers and a great reason for you to join a local hackerspace.

BeagleBone Black takes a central role in many developers' approach to connecting devices to the Internet, mostly thanks to its high-quality support of Linux, high-availability and extensive I/O capabilities. With Google's Dart language now running nicely, support in Canonical's announcement of Snappy Ubuntu Core for Internet Things, and uncountable IoT frameworks, possible ways to shortcut your design keep getting shorter. Learning all the relevant skills can still be rather time consuming, so it is great to see thought leaders like Brian Delacy of MIT explore how to fight through the mysteries of IoT in the most expedient way.
